subject: [TRAIN ONLY] Check for correct file during --skip-deploy-identifier handling.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-01-22 15:19:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/68d18d18deedaeb561f485617f9cf081656a9e14', 'message': 'Check for correct file during --skip-deploy-identifier handling.

At some point, the file names that are checked for existence when
determining to apply the logic for --skip-deploy-identifier must have
changed.

Since the file check was not updated, it was checking for a file that
would never exist, and so the ansible tasks were always run (or re-run).

Effectively, --skip-deploy-identifier was broken and it had no effect.

This patch updates the file check to use the correct name, and also

Change-Id: Ia01a10c488d22e38cd86b0117e9c048ea5cc3298
Closes-Bug: #1860566
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2020-01-22 15:22:38.000000000', 'files': ['common/deploy-steps.j2'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/b1ac5e1e2bd793774657f0e2e67721f8218dc92b', 'message': '[TRAIN ONLY] Check for correct file during --skip-deploy-identifier handling.

commit_message:
[TRAIN ONLY] Check for correct file during --skip-deploy-identifier handling.

At some point, the file names that are checked for existence when
determining to apply the logic for --skip-deploy-identifier must have
changed.

Since the file check was not updated, it was checking for a file that
would never exist, and so the ansible tasks were always run (or re-run).

Effectively, --skip-deploy-identifier was broken and it had no effect.

This patch updates the file check to use the correct name, and also
checks the right file per step. It only applies to Train since on
master, these files were switched to write out per container files in a
directory, and the fix was addressed at that time.

Change-Id: Ia01a10c488d22e38cd86b0117e9c048ea5cc3298
Closes-Bug: #1860566
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/17/703817/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: Check if /var/lib/tripleo-config/container-startup-config-step_1.json already exists stat: path: /var/lib/tripleo-config/container-startup-config-step_1.json when: (deploy_identifier is defined and deploy_identifier != "" and deploy_identifier is not none) or (container_startup_configs_json_stat is defined and not container_startup_configs_json_stat.stat.exists) - name: Check if /var/lib/tripleo-config/container-startup-config-step_{{ step }}.json already exists stat: path: /var/lib/tripleo-config/container-startup-config-step_{{ step }}.json
deleted_lines: - name: Check if /var/lib/tripleo-config/container-startup-config-1.json already exists stat: path: /var/lib/tripleo-config/container-startup-config-1.json when: - ((deploy_identifier is defined and deploy_identifier != "" and deploy_identifier is not none) or not container_startup_configs_json_stat.stat.exists) - name: Check if /var/lib/tripleo-config/container-startup-config-1.json already exists stat: path: /var/lib/tripleo-config/container-startup-config-1.json

commit_message:
Add network vip mapping into service data

Make it possible to resolve network virtual ips from
within a service template. The data is transported in
the existing ServiceData property wich is wired into
all services.

The data can be consumed in service templates, replacing
the need for hiera interpolation for network virtual ips.

Related: RHBZ#1791338
Closes-Bug: #1860545
Change-Id: I24c239174d8d066bd2cb4300a21fa1d38a3e80cd
(cherry picked from commit eac636c9e66cde459bc1e1802a67f00136b9734e)

Make it possible to resolve network virtual ips from
within a service template. The data is transported in

the need for hiera interpolation for network virtual ips.

subject: Introduce a new L3 agent mode -- dvr_bridge
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-01-10 04:17:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs/commit/1b11712daa5a548131d5ad52fa93e616f579fbba', 'message': 'Introduce a new l3-agent mode -- dvr-bridge

 Utilizing the existing framework for enabling different versions of
 dvr on a node, dvr-bridge is an agent mode for the l3-agent which tries
 to remove all references to the Linux kernel utilities and instead uses Open
 vSwitch utilities (which in certain modes can result in the same actions
 under the hood). This change creates a layer of abstraction for the
 l3-agent, enabling it to run on other platforms.

Change-Id: I899b9334b9994425a128f88222f16b5fd56beffe
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2019-01-14 18:28:19.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs/commit/df3a2b6f3284922ff24f33ca50097e09cc814394', 'message': 'Introduce a new l3-agent mode -- dvr_bridge

Utilizing the existing framework for enabling different versions of
DVR on a node, dvr_bridge is an agent mode for the l3-agent which tries
to remove all references to the Linux kernel utilities and instead use
Open vSwitch (which in certain modes can result in the same actions
under the hood). This change also includes  the creation of a layer of
abstraction for the l3-agent, enabling it to run on other platforms.

Related-Bug: #1705536

Change-Id: I899b9334b9994425a128f88222f16b5fd56beffe
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2019-01-14 19:37:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs/commit/f73918b669e43470219c8b19759945671baf70fe', 'message': 'Introduce a new l3-agent mode -- dvr_bridge

Utilizing the existing framework for enabling different versions of
DVR on a node, dvr_bridge is an agent mode for the l3-agent which tries
to remove all references to the Linux kernel utilities and instead use
Open vSwitch (which in certain modes can result in the same actions
under the hood). This change also includes  the creation of a layer of

Related-Bug: #1705536

Change-Id: I899b9334b9994425a128f88222f16b5fd56beffe
'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2019-01-18 00:18:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs/commit/2ffbcb7a590281d329359bfefe3485296c3882bc', 'message': 'Introduce a new L3 agent mode -- dvr_bridge

Utilizing the existing framework for enabling different versions of
DVR on a node, dvr_bridge is an agent mode for the L3 agent which tries
to remove all references to the Linux kernel utilities and instead use
Open vSwitch (which in certain modes can result in the same actions
under the hood).

This change also includes the creation of a layer of
abstraction for the L3 agent, thus decoupling it from the backend:
- Linux kernel utilities, iptables, namespaces (like before)
- Open vSwitch (the backend being introduced)
- <open possibilities>

Related-Bug: #1705536

Co-Authored-By: Igor D.C. <igor.duarte.cardoso@intel.com>

Change-Id: I899b9334b9994425a128f88222f16b5fd56beffe
'}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2019-04-06 00:16:11.000000000', 'files': ['specs/stein/dvr-bridge.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs/commit/d1f2d695a7db201790e2917f77b7b98a047d7cc4', 'message': 'Introduce a new L3 agent mode -- dvr_bridge

Utilizing the existing framework for enabling different versions of
DVR on a node, dvr_bridge is an agent mode for the L3 agent which tries
to remove all references to the Linux kernel utilities and instead use
Open vSwitch (which in certain modes can result in the same actions
under the hood).

This change also includes the creation of a layer of
abstraction for the L3 agent, thus decoupling it from the backend:
- Linux kernel utilities, iptables, namespaces (like before)
- Open vSwitch (the backend being introduced)

commit_message:
Introduce a new L3 agent mode -- dvr_bridge

Utilizing the existing framework for enabling different versions of
DVR on a node, dvr_bridge is an agent mode for the L3 agent which tries
to remove all references to the Linux kernel utilities and instead use
Open vSwitch (which in certain modes can result in the same actions
under the hood).

This change also includes the creation of a layer of
abstraction for the L3 agent, thus decoupling it from the backend:
- Linux kernel utilities, iptables, namespaces (like before)
- Open vSwitch (the backend being introduced)
- <open possibilities>

Related-Bug: #1705536

Co-Authored-By: Igor D.C. <igor.duarte.cardoso@intel.com>
Partially-Implements: blueprint openflow-based-dvr

Change-Id: I899b9334b9994425a128f88222f16b5fd56beffe
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/61/629761/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================ DVR Bridge, Experimental Open vSwitch Agent Mode ================================================ https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1705536 Problem Description =================== The use of linux network namespaces in the l3 agent routers causes a choke point for bandwidth on east/west and north/south traffic. In the case of east/west traffic, the source and destination interfaces are known to Neutron and could be routed using Open vSwitch if it is selected as the mechanism_driver for the L2-agent. This also makes the l3-agent incompatible with DPDK and Windows. Proposed Change =============== By introducing a new agent_mode to the l3-agent the use of an Open vSwitch backend can be introduced without the need of creating mechanism drivers similar to the L2 agent. This proposed agent_mode, hence refered to as "dvr_bridge"[1], will use Open vSwitch Bridges as a substitute for linux network namespaces. These routers are passed an iface_id when and interface is created and the L2-agent will assign a vlan_tag to the bridges patch ports when their creation is detected. This will cause the traffic on the br-int to be automatically sent to the relevant "dvr bridge" when it encounters a "Normal" action in the br-int flow table. As a result "dvr_bridge" requires no changes to the br-int flow table or the L2-agent. In order to route traffic to the correct destination, OpenFlow rules are used to emulate kernal routes. This involves classifying the traffic, decrementing the time to live, updating the mac information and outputing it to the appropriate port for east/west traffic. In the case of north/south traffic, the same workflow is used however the destination mac addresses are not available from neutron. For north/south traffic, arp requests are generate through the use of flows which convert local arp requests into arp requests targeting the external gateways. These requests are used by learn action flows, to generate flows with the required mac information for the packet to be forwarded to the next hop. As there will not be an interfaces created in the dataplane for these dvr bridges, OpenFlow flows will be used to convert ICMP/ARP requests into replies. These flows will also follow the same workflow described above. These changes would result in the performance of L3 traffic approaching that of L2 traffic. This is explained below: DataPlane East/West overview [FURTHER READING] l3 ping packet flow in dvr mode(simplified to ignore broadcast): logical: - the arp packet is received from the source vm and logically vlan tagged(tenant isolation) - the arp packet is output to the router tap device(tap1), the vlan is striped and the packet is copied from the ovs dataplane to the kernel networking stack in the routers linux namespace. - the kernel network stack replies to the arp and the reply packet is copied to the ovs dataplane and it is logically vlan tagged - the vlan is logically striped and the arp reply switched to the source vm interface. - the icmp packet is received from the source vm and logically vlan tagged(tenant isolation) - the icmp packet is output to the route tap device, the vlan is striped and the packet is copied from the ovs dataplane to the kernel networking stack in the routers linux namespace. - the kernel generates an arp request to the destination vm which follows the same path as the arp described above - the kernel modifies the dest mac address, decrements the ttl and routes the packet to the appropriate tap device(tap2) where the packet is copied to the ovs dataplane and it is logically vlan tagged - the vlan is logically striped and the icmp packet switched to the destination vm interface. - the reply path is similarly and is shortened as follows: destvm->vlan tagged->vlan stripped -> copied to kernel name space via tap2-> copied to ovs dataplane via tap1-> vlan tagged-> vlan stripped-> received by source vm. actual: - arp form source vm -> tap1 (vlan tagging skipped) + broadcast to other ports - tap1-> kernel network stack - kernel sends arp reply tap1 - tap1-> source vm (vlan tagging skipped) - icmp from source vm -> tap1(vlan tagging skipped) - kernel receives icmp on tap1 and send arp request to dest vm via tap2(broadcast) - arp via tap2 -> dest vm (vlan tagging skipped) - dest vm replies -> tap2 - kernel updates dest mac and decrement ttl the forward icmp packet to tap2 - tap2 -> dest vm-> dest vm replies->tap2.(vlan tagging skipped) - kernel updates dest mac and decrement ttl the forward icmp reply packet to tap1 - tap1-> source vm l3 packet flow in dvr_bridge mode: logical: - the arp packet is received from the source vm and logically vlan tagged(tenant isolation) - the arp packet is output to the router bridge patch port , and the vlan is stripped - the arp request is rewritten into a reply and sent back to the br-int and logically vlan tagged - the vlan is logically striped and the arp reply switched to the source vm interface. - the icmp packet is received from the source vm and logically vlan tagged(tenant isolation) - the icmp packet is output to the router bridge patch port , the vlan is striped. - the icmp packet matches the high priority rule and its mac is updated the it is output to the second patch port and it is logically vlan tagged - the vlan is logically striped and the icmp packet switched to the destination vm interface. - the reply path is similarly and is shortened as follows: destvm->vlan tagged->vlan stripped -> router bridge via patch 2-> mac and ttl updated then output patch 1-> vlan tagged-> vlan stripped-> received by source vm. actual: - arp form source vm -> arp rewritten to reply -> sent to source vm ( single openflow action). - icmp from source vm -> destination mac update, ttl decremented -> dest vm ( single openflow action) - icmp from dest vm -> destination mac update, ttl decremented -> source vm ( single openflow action) References ========== [1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/neutron_drivers/2017/neutron_drivers.2017-08-31-22.03.log.html#l-147

this prevents us pulling in critical fixes to unblock testing by
updating the sha of tempest.

commit_message:
Bump heat service sha

This updates heat to the head of the heat branch to include change
adac77a. This enables the heat keystone endpoint to be defined via
a new heat config variable.

commit_message:
Adapt tempestconf job to use integrated repo

Adapt the tempestconf job to use a variant of the integrated repo's
AIO test job.

Also mark tripleo CI job as non voting as it is failing.

commit_message:
Fix the interface filenames for Red Hat amphora images

Code was not using the correct filenames for the 'route',
'route6', 'rule' and 'rule6' files on Red Hat images.
Changed to use config option 'agent_server_network_file'
if it's specified, else the file of the correct name, and
added unit tests for each.

Change-Id: I335287da66524d026f0c42086d885b478c568bbd
Task: 37881
Story: 2007051

added_lines: if CONF.amphora_agent.agent_server_network_file: return CONF.amphora_agent.agent_server_network_file if CONF.amphora_agent.agent_server_network_dir: return os.path.join(CONF.amphora_agent.agent_server_network_dir, 'ifcfg-' + interface) network_dir = consts.RH_AMP_NET_DIR_TEMPLATE.format( netns=consts.AMPHORA_NAMESPACE) return os.path.join(network_dir + 'route-' + interface)

subject: Validate the playboooks metadata structure
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-01-15 10:08:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-validations/commit/5156beda6d59cee44ab3bddbce72a48db00b7af3', 'message': 'Validate the playboooks metadata structure

This patch add a custom ansible-lint rule to enforce the structure of
the validations playbooks:

*ValidationHasMetadataRule*:
Throw an ansible-lint error if:
- the *hosts* key is empty or not found,
- *vars* dictionary is missing,
- *metadata* dict is missing in *vars*
- *name*/*description*/*groups* keys are missing or found with a wrong
  data type
- the validation belongs to one or several groups NOT in the official list of
  groups (groups.yaml)

*YAMLLINT*:
- Enable yamllint check in tox linters

commit_message:
Validate the playboooks metadata structure

This patch add a custom ansible-lint rule to enforce the structure of
the validations playbooks:

*ValidationHasMetadataRule*:
Throw an ansible-lint error if:
- the *hosts* key is empty or not found,
- *vars* dictionary is missing,
- *metadata* dict is missing in *vars*
- *name*/*description*/*groups* keys are missing or found with a wrong
  data type
- the validation belongs to one or several groups NOT in the official list of
  groups (groups.yaml)

*YAMLLINT*:
- Enable yamllint check in tox linters
- WIP Fix detected yamllint errors

Change-Id: If233286aa9f4299f02f13dc34f1e8c05d89df851
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit e50e1a067de6d359d8e95c909859c30cf5d6912e)
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Run multinode and undercloud jobs nova-less

None of these jobs actually use nova, so it should be possible to run
them without.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/703038/

Change-Id: I472f8d146d865316da4066cc6845e23c8808c907
Blueprint: nova-less-deploy

subject: L3 agent refactor: RouterInfo and Backend
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-02-27 09:17:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/8831132c4deb98e85c447e07bb15b00d16636879', 'message': '[WIP] L3 agent refactor: RouterInfo and Backend

Mostly finished but still WIP.

Change-Id: If191289ca380b9c946ae1954f724e37240b0c839
Related-Bug: #1705536
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2019-03-04 05:51:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/37cdcd95872570f23cc8b38f569052d5fe4674db', 'message': '[WIP] L3 agent refactor: RouterInfo and Backend

Mostly finished but still WIP.

L3 agent refactor: towards backend-agnostic agent

This patch fundamentally does 3 things to make the l3 agent.py agnostic
of which backend is being used to implement the routers being deployed.

1. Introduce the Backend class hierarchy
Backend is a abstract class meant to normalize the operations that any
backend (such as Linux or OVS) should implement. Its children will
carry out backend-specific operations. At the moment, Backend will
only be for operations that the agent as a whole requires. Operations
needed in the context of a specific Router that is being managed are
not to be fulfilled by the Backend hierarchy.

2. Refactor RouterInfo a little bit by moving some code to Backend
children instead (specifically to LinuxBackend since Linux is the only
backend currently available). The code that has been moved is thus
code that is required by the agent as a whole, not by any particular
router. Additinally, RouterInfo gets renamed to LinuxRouterInfo and
a new parent class is created called "RouterInfo". The latter
RouterInfo is an abstract class aims at unifying the interface to be
supported by any backend implementation of RouterInfo, very much like
the Backend class. The difference in the case of RouterInfo is that
it will be meant for operations in the context of particular routers.

3. Modify agent.py/mixins to make use of both RouterInfo and Backend.
Specifically, it is making use of LinuxRouterInfo and LinuxBackend
since those are the only backends available at this point. A lot of
renaming in many different files has been done too, mainly due to
original RouterInfo becoming LinuxRouterInfo.

The commit message will be shortened once there's documentation.

Related-Bug: #1705536
Change-Id: If191289ca380b9c946ae1954f724e37240b0c839
'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2019-03-04 07:01:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/19fdc1a0d438f0149aea5e770b6e73833d866cf7', 'message': '[WIP] L3 agent refactor: RouterInfo and Backend

commit_message:
L3 agent refactor: RouterInfo and Backend

This patch fundamentally does 2 things to make the l3 agent.py agnostic
of which backend is being used to implement the routers being deployed.

1. Introduce the Backend class hierarchy
Backend is a abstract class meant to normalize the operations that any
backend (such as Linux or OVS) should implement. Its children will
carry out backend-specific operations. At the moment, Backend will
only be for operations that the agent as a whole requires. Operations
needed in the context of a specific Router that is being managed are
not to be fulfilled by the Backend hierarchy.

2. Refactor RouterInfo a little bit by moving some code to Backend
children instead (specifically to LinuxBackend since Linux is the only
backend currently available). The code that has been moved is thus
code that is required by the agent as a whole, not by any particular
router. Additionally, this patch now depends on patch 620349, which
introduces BaseRouterInfo and the router_factory.
BaseRouterInfo is an abstract class to unify the interface to be
supported by any backend implementation of RouterInfo, very much like
the Backend class. The difference in the case of RouterInfo is that
it will be meant for operations in the context of particular routers.

Related-Bug: #1705536
Change-Id: If191289ca380b9c946ae1954f724e37240b0c839
Partially-Implements: blueprint openflow-based-dvr

commit_message:
Introduce agent_backend L3 option

This patch introduces the agent_backend option to be
used in the L3 agent configuration file. The single
value supported as of now is "linux", reflecting the
backend that the L3 agent has always supported.

Partially-Implements: blueprint openflow-based-dvr
Related-Bug: #1705536
Change-Id: I5f382631ba3ae2ec537380502b9c5070a04c25d0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/49/642249/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron.common import constants as n_const cfg.StrOpt('agent_backend', default=n_const.L3_AGENT_BACKEND_LINUX, choices=(n_const.L3_AGENT_BACKEND_LINUX,), help=_("What technology the agent will use to deploy routers. " "Allowed values are: 'linux' - which makes use of " "Linux kernel technologies such as network namespaces " "and the IP stack to instantiate virtual routers. This " "is the default and single backend implemented.")),

commit_message:
Add new option to enable unbuildable images

I7a92b762f6a783f92ebca61e5595e1422a92df4f added checking for unbuildable
images when someone wants just templates (like TripleO for example).

But what if someone wants all images despite their buildability status?
Or wants to build for some new distro/arch combo?

--enable-unbuildable just ignores internal UNBUILDABLE_IMAGES list and
tries all images.

Change-Id: I20312b9719c6f5e3dca0b4198607ddae183152f1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/11/704311/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix kill-script

This change squashes two changes that are being backported from the
tripleo-ansible repo.  They are to the same file, which was relocated to
tripleo-ansible between Train and Ussuri.

Change https://review.opendev.org/703123: In the kill-script there is a
string "Unknown action ${SIG} for ${$CT_NAME} ${CT_ID}" which results in
a "bad substitution" error, as there is no variable named with what the
contents of the CT_NAME environment variable contains.  Remove the
extraneous '$'.

Change https://review.opendev.org/703128: The reason bug #1860155 was
triggered was because the kill script did not have a stanza for handling
the signal that was passed in, which is signal 15.  Since signal 15 is
unhandled, keepalived processes will still stick around.  Add handling
for signal 15.

Change-Id: Ib47fc73b498b6366efa4ae5b16855bd45cb3ec91
Fixes-Bug: #1860155
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/63/704463/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: signal_container() { SIGNAL=$3 if [ -z "$SIGNAL" ]; then SIGNAL="HUP" fi add_date "Sending signal '$SIGNAL' to $1 ($2)" $CLI kill --signal $SIGNAL $2 signal_container $CT_NAME $CT_ID 15) signal_container $CT_NAME $CT_ID ;; add_date "Unknown action ${SIG} for ${CT_NAME} ${CT_ID}"
deleted_lines: hup_container() { add_date "Sending HUP signal to $1 ($2)" $CLI kill --signal HUP $2 hup_container $CT_NAME $CT_ID add_date "Unknown action ${SIG} for ${$CT_NAME} ${CT_ID}"

commit_message:
Fix ansible-runner when verbosity is > 0

This change updates the run_ansible_playbook method to ensure that we're not
attempting to re-open the ansible runner stdout property when executing a
task with a verbosity setting of > 0. When the property is read the tmp file
has already been cleaned up resulting in stacktrace. There's no value in
re-opening the property as stdout is already been presented to the user so
the offending code has been deleted.

Change-Id: I4ab300e8a2a70adb1f79334aee44fde31d2cfa70
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Create default network for more compute tests

Chipping away at the referenced bug, this commit uses the
create_default_network class-level variable introduced via [1] to
trigger setup_credentials to create a default network for another test
case in which the problem was observed.

[1] Ia34fe3b41261de02918713c2a948e6c56554bf6f
Partial-Bug: #1844568

commit_message:
Allow archival for big files

Archive any file over 10KB when artcl_gzip is set to true.

Remember that not all jobs running are yet using this role. We will
sort this aspect after enabling this role.

Molecule testing job should validate the archival logic.

Change-Id: I044cd56473762d6d5c9318e1c76e43b454b4c7b6
Needed-By: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/704044/

commit_message:
Ensure boolean is cast to bool

This will ensure all potential ansible accepted boolean operators are
trapped and handled correctly.

Change-Id: Ifbc293860cc81c0c689b127b2da8930f557a6ad5
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fix test_stamp_pattern to remove dependency of user supplied volume name

This patch removes CONF.compute.volume_device_name dependency and
use modified list_disks method to get the newly attached
device name and use that for mkfs rather than the user supplied
device name which is based on assumtion.

Also modfied test_attach_detach testcase and unit test
for remote_client accordingly.

Change-Id: I862d1ba55f45b09385057a51b0b52a851c19287e
Closes-Bug: #1852807

Tempest modifies the base url fetched from endpoints by truncating the
whole path which is incorrect in case of registered endpoint with an
extra path, like in a case of Rados GW.

Normally a swift url is organised as host:port/info and
host:port/v1/AUTH_<tenant-id>, see
https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/object-store/
But RadosGW API is organised as host:port/swift/info and
host:port/swift/v1/AUTH_<tenant-id>, see
https://docs.ceph.com/docs/master/radosgw/config-ref/#swift-settings

Change-Id: I6a932639a05defe0f04c600afcc35a19662937af
Close-bug: 1799981

commit_message:
Accept custom registered endpoints

The review drops usage of skip_path() filter in the related tests
and uses raw_request() instead.

Normally a swift url is organised as host:port/info and
host:port/v1/AUTH_<tenant-id>, see
https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/object-store/
But RadosGW API is organised as host:port/swift/info and
host:port/swift/v1/AUTH_<tenant-id>, see
https://docs.ceph.com/docs/master/radosgw/config-ref/#swift-settings

Close-bug: 1799981
Change-Id: I6a932639a05defe0f04c600afcc35a19662937af

added_lines: class TestSkipFromVersion(base.TestCase): def test_url_version_path(self): self.assertEqual( 'http://localhost:35357', auth.skip_from_version('http://localhost:35357/v2.0')) def test_url_version_path_with_prefix(self): self.assertEqual( 'http://localhost:35357/api_prefix', auth.skip_from_version('http://localhost:35357/api_prefix/v2.0')) def test_url_version_path_with_prefix2(self): url = 'http://localhost:35357/api_prefix/v2.0/volume' self.assertEqual( 'http://localhost:35357/api_prefix', auth.skip_from_version(url)) def test_url_with_prefix(self): self.assertEqual( 'http://localhost:35357/api_prefix', auth.skip_from_version('http://localhost:35357/api_prefix')) def test_url_no_version_no_prefix(self): self.assertEqual( 'http://localhost:35357', auth.skip_from_version('http://localhost:35357')) def test_url_no_version_no_prefix_trailing_slash(self): self.assertEqual( 'http://localhost:35357/', auth.skip_from_version('http://localhost:35357/'))

commit_message:
Support nested domains to provide additional project namespaces

Allow customers to utilise sub-domains to create namespaces
within a parent domain, so as to alleviate the restrictions of
project name constraints.

This spec is indended as an alternative to the proposals for
relaxing the project name constraints and supporting
hierarchical project naming, see:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/310048
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/318605

Change-Id: I9e65d595b18ee3e498176d057f0f1ee1a68ad572
Implements: blueprint hierarchical-domains
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/40/332940/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================ Support hierarchical domains ============================ `bp hierarchical-domains <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/hierarchical-domains>`_ Allow a sub-domains to be created for the purposes of providing additional name spacing. Problem Description =================== Due to our heritage of a flat tenant model, a project's name must be unique within a domain, regardless of where that project sits in any project hierarchy within that domain. As project hierarchies grow, this will become increasingly untenable. A common requirement is to have similar hierarchies for product phases, for example: "projectA/development" "projectA/staging" "projectA/production" "projectB/development" "projectB/staging" "projectB/production" The above is not currently possible, since each project name must be unique within a domain. Using separate domains for projectA and projectB is conceptually possible, but in practice is hard to administer, for instance: - If the users are in LDAP, then this configuration must be duplicated - Assignments would need to duplicated manually between the domains - The cloud admin (think public cloud) would have to be involved every time a customer wanted to add a domain to create a new name space - The top level project (which is now a domain) must be unique across all other domains (again, think of the implications for that in a public cloud). While a longer term goal may be to relax the project uniqueness constraint, this would affect many clients of keystone. An alternative, is therefore being proposed to make the solution of using domains more tenable. Proposed Change =============== The proposal is to support hierarchical domains, so that a domain admin can create new namespaces for the purposes of allowing hierarchies of the type described above to exist. Since we already store domains as projects, this is essentially extending the project hierarchy to include hierarchical domains. The change would be implemented by: - The parent of a domain is always a domain - i.e. the domains are always at the top end of the tree. - No change to the uniqueness constraint of project names within a domain. - Domain names always contain the path to the root. This does not affect the names of existing domains (since there are only top level domains today), but only new (sub) domains. i.e. if an existing domain called "foo" has a sub domain created called "bar", the name of that sub-domain will be "foo/bar". Hence domain names remain unique across all domains. This name can be used as a domain name in an authentication scoped, just as can existing (top level) domain names. - Creating a sub domain will only be possible via the project API (which has built in support for hierarchies). The existing domain API will see sub domains (with the name as the path) and can perform any other CRUD operation (except create). In Mitaka, we laid the ground work for allowing the specification of a path in an API request, by supporting an optional ability to make sure domain/project names are url safe [1]. Deployments that are running with this feature enabled could reliably use a hierarchical naming scheme (with a separator that is one of the reserved characters defined in section 2.2 of rfc3986 <http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3986>_) to reference a domain, if we were to provide one. For example: :: { "auth": { "identity": { ... }, "scope": { "project": { "domain": { "name": "acme.com/projectA" }, "name": "production" } } } } It is proposed that we now enable this capability, as part of a microversion change of the Identity API. A 3.7 server will also default 'url_safe' to 'strict' mode. We will mark this config option as deprecated, so that we can remove the ability to turn it off in two releases. Until that point, if strictness is turned off in a 3.7 or 3.8 server, then a path name will no longer be accepted in the auth request. Since domains only exist at the top level in v3.6, there will be no compatibility impact for 3.6 clients - existing use of domain name will work as it does today, as it will if the client upgrades to 3.7. A 3.6 client is speaking to a Newton server, will see any new sub-domains that have been created with the name including the path - which they can use directly in any 3.6 API that takes a domain name (including auth). One issue to be aware of is that currently the domain name is sized at 64 characters - by definition if we are returning a path in this attribute this size will need to increase. The maximum depth of the domain hierarchy will be controlled by a config value (in a similar way to the existing non-domain project hierarchy depth is controlled). Clients will need to take account of this size increase of this attribute. The separator used in such path naming will be the forward slash character `/`. It would be possible to make the separator configurable by deployment via a configuration option - however the confusion of having to know the separator for a given cloud (before you authenticate), seems to create a worse problem than simply having a fixed separator in the first place, so it is proposed that we do not allow the separator to be modified. In order to not have to have assignments replicated manually between the domains, the domain entity will be augmented to add an attribute that enables assignments to be inherited to sub domains below it (and hence to any projects below them). Such inheritance will be off by default. Alternatives ------------ Two other alternatives have been discussed to get round the uniqueness constrain: - Relax the constrain entirely - `<https://review.openstack.org/#/c/310048>`_ - Hierarchical project naming - `<https://review.openstack.org/#/c/318605>`_ Data Model Impact ----------------- We could chose to store the name for new domains (created via 3.7 or later) as their full path (in which case the field size must be increased since it is currently 64 characters), or calculate the path on-demand. REST API Impact --------------- See Identity specification changes proposed as part of this patch. Security Impact --------------- None Notifications Impact -------------------- Whenever we issue notifications that reference a domain name, this will be a fully qualified path from the root to the domain within the hierarchy. Other End User Impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other Deployer Impact --------------------- None Developer Impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: henry-nash Dependencies ============ Microversion support in Keystone, see: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/315180/ Testing ======= Tempest tests will be provided that ensure introduction of this feature does not break existing expectations of other services. Documentation Impact ==================== Changes to the Identity API to clarify naming. References ========== [1] `url-safe-names <https://github.com/openstack/keystone-specs/blob/master/specs/keystone/mitaka/url-safe-names.rst>_`.

commit_message:
Allow admin to specify project id on creation

Implements bp admin-to-create-project-with-id

Change-Id: I5172b9fe19a2a8e424e47b6d5ece900337cc6ded
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/99/323499/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================= Allow admin to specify project id on creation ============================================= `bp admin-to-create-project-with-id <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/admin-to-create-project-with-id>`_ Problem Description =================== If a project or domain is deleted, this will allow the re-creation of the domain, or at least a reasonable facimile of it. The new domain or project can have the same ID as an existing one, an thus can be enabled, and a user can get a token scoped to that domain or project. Since Fernet tokens have been developed it becomes possible to implement pure multi-region architecture. It is necessary to have same role IDs, same Project IDs and same User IDs in all regions. Fernet keys should be the same across the regions as well. In this case a user may generate the token in one region and present it to any service in any region, and tis token will be successfully validated by any Keystone. This approach allows to operate in different regions with much more flexibility since the user doesn't have to communicate with different endpoints anymore. Horizon will allow to operate in different regions within one session as well. It would be pretty easy to pre-create projects and assignments based on the remote groups (LDAP), but there is a key problem. Main problem at the moment - it is impossible to create same IDs of the projects if Keystone v3 API is used since Project ID is always been generated (in v2 though it was possible to set project ID upon creation). Proposed Change =============== Modify keystone project creation code so that it will not generate a new ID for created project if it is explicitly provided in the API call. Alternatives ------------ What other ways could we do this thing? Why aren't we using those? This doesn't have to be a full literature review, but it should demonstrate that thought has been put into why the proposed solution is an appropriate one. Security Impact --------------- Describe any potential security impact on the system. Some of the items to consider include: * Does this change touch sensitive data such as tokens, keys, or user data? * Does this change alter the API in a way that may impact security, such as a new way to access sensitive information or a new way to login? * Does this change involve cryptography or hashing? * Does this change require the use of sudo or any elevated privileges? * Does this change involve using or parsing user-provided data? This could be directly at the API level or indirectly such as changes to a cache layer. * Can this change enable a resource exhaustion attack, such as allowing a single API interaction to consume significant server resources? Some examples of this include launching subprocesses for each connection, or entity expansion attacks in XML. For more detailed guidance, please see the OpenStack Security Guidelines as a reference (https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Security/Guidelines). These guidelines are a work in progress and are designed to help you identify security best practices. For further information, feel free to reach out to the OpenStack Security Group at openstack-security@lists.openstack.org. Notifications Impact -------------------- Please specify any changes to notifications. Be that an extra notification, changes to an existing notification, or removing a notification. Other End User Impact --------------------- Aside from the API, are there other ways a user will interact with this feature? * Does this change have an impact on python-keystoneclient? What does the user interface there look like? Performance Impact ------------------ Describe any potential performance impact on the system, for example how often will new code be called, and is there a major change to the calling pattern of existing code. Examples of things to consider here include: * A small change in a utility function or a commonly used decorator can have a large impacts on performance. * Calls which result in a database queries can have a profound impact on performance when called in critical sections of the code. * Will the change include any locking, and if so what considerations are there on holding the lock? Other Deployer Impact --------------------- Discuss things that will affect how you deploy and configure OpenStack that have not already been mentioned, such as: * What config options are being added? Should they be more generic than proposed (for example a flag that other hypervisor drivers might want to implement as well)? Are the default values ones which will work well in real deployments? * Is this a change that takes immediate effect after its merged, or is it something that has to be explicitly enabled? * If this change is a new binary, how would it be deployed? * Please state anything that those doing continuous deployment, or those upgrading from the previous release, need to be aware of. Also describe any plans to deprecate configuration values or features. For example, if we change the directory name that instances are stored in, how do we handle instance directories created before the change landed? Do we move them? Do we have a special case in the code? Do we assume that the operator will recreate all the instances in their cloud? Developer Impact ---------------- Discuss things that will affect other developers working on OpenStack, such as: * If the blueprint proposes a change to the driver API, discussion of how other backends would implement the feature is required. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Who is leading the writing of the code? Or is this a blueprint where you're throwing it out there to see who picks it up? If more than one person is working on the implementation, please designate the primary author and contact. Primary assignee: <launchpad-id or None> Other contributors: <launchpad-id or None> Work Items ---------- Work items or tasks -- break the feature up into the things that need to be done to implement it. Those parts might end up being done by different people, but we're mostly trying to understand the timeline for implementation. Dependencies ============ * Include specific references to specs and/or blueprints in keystone, or in other projects, that this one either depends on or is related to. * If this requires functionality of another project that is not currently used by Keystone (such as the glance v2 API when we previously only required v1), document that fact. * Does this feature require any new library dependencies or code otherwise not included in OpenStack? Or does it depend on a specific version of library? Documentation Impact ==================== What is the impact on the docs team of this change? Some changes might require donating resources to the docs team to have the documentation updated. Don't repeat details discussed above, but please reference them here. References ========== Please add any useful references here. You are not required to have any reference. Moreover, this specification should still make sense when your references are unavailable. Examples of what you could include are: * Links to mailing list or IRC discussions * Links to notes from a summit session * Links to relevant research, if appropriate * Related specifications as appropriate (e.g. if it's an EC2 thing, link the EC2 docs) * Anything else you feel it is worthwhile to refer to

subject: Repropose Expiring Group Membership for Ussuri
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-12-13 16:22:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs/commit/b24ccda6a920b747566845affbbcddd9a1549f78', 'message': 'Repropose Expiring Group Membership for Ussuri

Add federated users to the groups that they receive from the mapping rules.
This membership is only carried by the token and not persisted in the
database. The membership expires, but can be renewed when the user
authenticates with the same group.

Previously approved for Train, fell into backlog, reproposing for Ussuri.

commit_message:
Repropose Expiring Group Membership for Ussuri

Add federated users to the groups that they receive from the mapping rules.
This membership is only carried by the token and not persisted in the
database. The membership expires, but can be renewed when the user
authenticates with the same group.

Previously approved for Train, fell into backlog, reproposing for Ussuri.

Change-Id: Ie133c14ffba5e4189265920759bfb5e1391f1189
Partial-Bug: 1809116

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-04-25 21:33:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/api-sig/commit/898db5f3937fe3a952e103388f6052d5e349ffda', 'message': "WIP Add guideline describing a cloud profile document

This is very early and rough. Basically, it's an outgrowth of
os-client-config's vendor profile documents, but adapted based on
lessons learned - and then suggested as a mostly-static document
deployers can deploy.

It is suggested as a static generatable document because:

a) It will change very infrequently, so serving it from a REST service
is not efficient.

b) If it's a document, a deployer running an older cloud can add one -
adding a single file to an apache/nginx config is not super hard.
Whereas adding a new REST service, or backporting a change to an
existing REST service is usually a no-go.

c) As a document, it's easily cachable by clients.

d) As a document, it's also something that a user can just store locally
if they happen to be using a cloud that for whatever reason refuses to
deploy a profile document.

That said - this patch in its current form is a complete brain-dump -
which is probably easy to see in the form of the prose. Help making the
text be less bad would be highly appreciated. Also - this is a proposal
for a thing which doens't exist and also doesn't have an associated REST
service to go with - which makes it a weird beast that has zero home in
our current governance structure. But the API-WG are the stewards of
helping make our APIs more consumable.

Change-Id: I6ba1e51ad38e96719a00cab2921a91e5fa0cc090

"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2017-04-27 12:45:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/api-sig/commit/3b9f4465c8e5dba5f1085d9f71f422f4bbeda485', 'message': "Add guideline describing a cloud profile document

This is an outgrowth of os-client-config's vendor profile documents,
but adapted based on lessons learned and suggested as a mostly-static
document deployers should deploy.

It is suggested as a static generatable document because:

a) It will change very infrequently, so serving it from a REST service
is not efficient.

b) If it's a document, a deployer running an older cloud can (and
should) add one - adding a single file to an apache/nginx config is
not super hard. Adding a new REST service, or backporting a change to an
existing REST service is usually a no-go.

c) As a mostly static document, it's easily cachable by clients.

d) As a static document, it's also something that a user can just store
locally as we currently do with os-client-config vendor profiles if they
happen to be using a cloud that for whatever reason refuses to
deploy a profile document. In fact, to start, os-client-config can
continue to store and ship documents for known public clouds until such
a time as those clouds start deploying them themselves.

If this is accepted, the ultimate intent would be to add support to
devstack (and the other upstream deployment projects) to add one to the
clouds they deploy, add tempest tests for it and propose it for
inclusion in DefCore guidelines. However, as this doesn't have an
associated REST service, it's a little bit of a weird beast that doesn't
have an explicit home in our current governance structure, so it would
probably be good, if the API-WG likes it, to make a proposal to the TC
to get buy in - and maybe a provisional nod from the Interop Working Group
that the idea of adding it to the guidelines at least wouldn't be
rejected outright.

Change-Id: I6ba1e51ad38e96719a00cab2921a91e5fa0cc090

commit_message:
Add guideline describing a cloud profile document

This is an outgrowth of os-client-config's vendor profile documents,
but adapted based on lessons learned and suggested as a mostly-static
document deployers should deploy.

It is suggested as a static generatable document because:

a) It will change very infrequently, so serving it from a REST service
is not efficient.

b) If it's a document, a deployer running an older cloud can (and
should) add one - adding a single file to an apache/nginx config is
not super hard. Adding a new REST service, or backporting a change to an
existing REST service is usually a no-go.

c) As a mostly static document, it's easily cachable by clients.

d) As a static document, it's also something that a user can just store
locally as we currently do with os-client-config vendor profiles if they
happen to be using a cloud that for whatever reason refuses to
deploy a profile document. In fact, to start, os-client-config can
continue to store and ship documents for known public clouds until such
a time as those clouds start deploying them themselves.

If this is accepted, the ultimate intent would be to add support to
devstack (and the other upstream deployment projects) to add one to the
clouds they deploy, add tempest tests for it and propose it for
inclusion in DefCore guidelines. However, as this doesn't have an
associated REST service, it's a little bit of a weird beast that doesn't
have an explicit home in our current governance structure, so it would
probably be good, if the API-WG likes it, to make a proposal to the TC
to get buy in - and maybe a provisional nod from the Interop Working
Group that the idea of adding it to the guidelines at least wouldn't be
rejected outright.

We know more things we can put in to this from os-client-config - but
let's start small-ish and see how we get.

Change-Id: I6ba1e51ad38e96719a00cab2921a91e5fa0cc090
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/api-sig refs/changes/69/459869/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. _cloud_profile: Cloud Profile ============= Background ---------- Each OpenStack cloud out there has a set of characteristics that are shaped by the deployment decisions made. Some of these can be inferred by clever exploration of the APIs, others are necessarily a-priori knowledge. Even in the places where a discovery API exists, it can add up to *several* API calls just to get started, even though the overall shape of the cloud itself does not change in any appreciable way. Via the os-client-config libraries, several tools, including python-openstackclient and shade, have been able to collect information on known clouds to improve this for their users, but those are only in Python, and that work does not help users of private clouds. In order to empower our cloud operators to continue making the decisions they need to, but to also communicate the API impact of those decisions to API users, the following recommendations are made. Profile Document ---------------- Each cloud should publish a static "profile" describing the End User impacts of the choices the deployer has made. The document only needs to be updated when the deployment is updated, so it is designed to be easily servable as a static file served by a normal web server. The cloud profile should send an ETag header so that it can be correctly and aggressively cached. **TODO** Expand on this to be a real description of how etags and cache control headers interact with this document. The cloud profile should readable by unauthenticated users. The cloud profile should be located at ``/profile.json`` on the main URL of the cloud in question. The cloud profile should be the primary endpoint communicated to users. The information in the cloud profile should be correct for the typical user. If there is a service that is only being rolled out to some users, it should not yet be listed in the cloud profile. If there is a feature that is only enabled for some users, it should not be listed in the cloud profile. .. note:: Followup information will be coming with information on how to expose features or services to a smaller subset of users. The cloud profile describes the 'public' interfaces of a cloud's services. A cloud may also publish a ``profile-internal.json`` and a ``profile-admin.json`` if they choose. OpenStack Clients should always accept a full URL to a cloud profile. Clouds may not add additional information to the cloud profile that is not in this spec. Updates to the cloud profile schema version are not tied to OpenStack releases. A deployer can deploy this cloud profile to a web server associated with a bexar OpenStack. The entire point of this document is to help users understand deployer choices. If a choice needs to be communicated to a user, it belongs in this specification. Only things that are not easily discoverable need to go into the cloud profile. The existence of the profile is not an invitation to invent tons of new things and put them there. The newer services tend to be pretty good about this. Feature discoverability needs to be done at the service level, but some things are old and intractable. It is recommended that it be placed on the main domain of the cloud in question. For instance, if Vexxhost runs a cloud on the domain ``vexxhost.net``, then the cloud profile should be served from ``https://vexxhost.net/profile.json``, but if Vexxhost has other business and their cloud is but a small part, such that the cloud is run from ``cloud.vexxhost.net``, then it should be served from ``https://cloud.vexxhost.net/profile.json``. Similarly, if there is an internal private cloud running on ``10.1.2.4``, the profile should be hosted at ``https://10.1.2.4/profile.json`` but if the entire cloud is below an suburl, such as ``https://10.1.2.3/openstack`` then the profile document should be served from ``https://10.1.2.3/openstack/profile.json``. This enables a deployed to say: "The cloud is at cloud.vexxhost.net" or "The cloud is at 10.1.2.3/openstack" and the user should be empowered to go from there. .. note:: This is intended to be a json document. It is in yaml format here for now for ease of reading/responding/commenting. Before we land this proposal, we'll expand it to json with a jsonschema and all that good stuff. .. code-block:: yaml profile: # Version of the schema for this profile document, not of the document # itself. This is a version of the form XXX.YYY. Adding new fields, or # new possible values to an enum should increase # Required. schema_version: 2.0 # Name of this cloud. For users with accounts on multiple clouds, will be # used to identify that they want to talk to this named cloud. It is # recommended to make this the same as the root of the URL hosting the # profile. # Required. name: example.com # Information needed by users to authenticate to the cloud auth: # keystone auth_url. can contain {region_name} as a substitution variable # to support clouds that do independent keystones per-region # Required. auth_url: https://identity.example.com # Is there a single global keystone auth_url, or is there an auth_url # per region? # Optional. Defaults to True. global_auth_url: True # list of auth plugins supported. # If the cloud uses or supports any auth plugins that are not in-tree # upstream, their entry should include a documentation link. Optionally, # if client support for the auth plugin is provided via plugins to other # programs or libraries, a list of dictionaries can be provided, keyed # on the name of the thing the plugin is a plugin for, with links to where # a user can find the plugin. If the plugin is a plugin for keystoneauth, # the key in the plugins list should be "keystoneauth". Other plugin # targets are freeform but care should be taken to be obvious. # Optional. Defaults to [{'name': 'password'}, {'name': 'token'}] plugins: - name: password - name: token - name: rackspace_apikey documentation: https://developer.rackspace.com/docs/cloud-identity/v2/api-reference/token-operations/#authenticate-as-user-with-password-or-api-key plugins: - keystoneauth: https://github.com/rackerlabs/rackspace-keystoneauth-plugin # Default plugin that users should use if they have no other specific # reasons to behave differently. # Optional. Defaults to password default_plugin: password web: # URL to web interface for the cloud. # Optional. Defaults to null interface: https://console.example.com # If the main web interface is not horizon but a horizon is also # available, this is its URL. # Optional. Defaults to null horizon: https://horizon.example.com # If the cloud supports self-service account creation, the URL where # the user can start that process. # Optional. Defaults to null account_url: https://join.example.com network: # List of available well-known networking architectures available # The values are: # v4-public - a user can boot a machine directly on a public network # v4-private - a user can create private networks # v4-nat - a user can create floating IPs # v6-public - a user can boot a machine with an IPv6 address # split-stack - a user is given a single network that provides private # v4 and public v6 by default # Required. architectures: - v4-public - v6-public - v4-nat # A fnmatch pattern indicating the cloud-provided v4 public network name # Optional. Defaults to null. public_v4_network_pattern: '*WAN*' # A fnmatch pattern indicating the cloud-provided v4 private network name # Optional. Defaults to null. private_v4_network_pattern: '*LAN*' image: # list of formats in which an image can be for upload. # Optional. Defaults to qcow2 formats: - qcow2 - raw # format the cloud prefers, in case more than one is accepted. defaults # to qcow2 preferred_format: qcow2 # Boolean - is image upload enabled by default. # Optional. Defaults to True. upload_enabled: true # If upload_enableed is False, but image upload can be enabled for some # users on a request-by-request basis, a link should be provided to docs # explaining how to request image upload. # Optional. Defaults to null upload_provisional_url: null # List of upload mechanisms. Vaules are: # v1-put - v1 REST PUT API # v2-put - v2 REST PUT API # v2-task - upload to swift and then v2 task-import API # v2-upload - v2 image upload API # Optional. Defaults to [v2-put] upload_mechanisms: - v1-put - v2-put compute: # How the cloud provides IPv4 network config to guests # Enum. Choices are ['dhcp', 'static'] # Optional. Defaults to dhcp v4-network-config: dhcp # How the cloud provides IPv6 network config to guests # Enum. Choices are [null, 'ra', 'dhcp'] **TODO** what are the choices? # Optional. Defaults to ra v6-network-config: ra # By default server snapshots are not live - they shut down the server # in question first. If the cloud operator has a new enough libvirt and # they have enabled it in the nova config, snapshots become live. live_snapshots: False # List of regions available in the cloud regions: - name: Dallas # Whether the region is enabled for everyone, must be requested or is # disabled. Values are true, false provisional. If the value is # provisional, provisional_url must be provided. Defaults to true enabled: true # URL describing how to request this region be enabled. Defaults to null provisional_url: null # List of Service dicts, each with a key name based on the key from # service-types-registry services: - service-type: compute # Unversioned Discovery URL for the Public Endpoint of the service. discovery-endpoint: https://compute.example.com # Cached copy of the content of the discovery URL aligned to the API-WG # spec versions: - status: CURRENT max_version: 2.38 min_version: 2.1 id: v2.1 links: - href: http://compute.example.com/v2.1 rel: self - status: SUPPORTED id: v2.0 links: - href: http://compute.example.com/v2 rel: self .. note:: A tool will be provided to take a smaller file that only contains the deployers answers and a normal user account and will expand those answers into a valid profile document. An example of a vendor input file for a cloud without too many modifications from the default follows. .. code-block:: yaml profile: name: simple.example.com auth: auth_url: https://simple.example.com/auth network: architectures: - v4-public - v6-public - v4-nat - v4-private regions: - name: Dallas

commit_message:
Add idempotent DELETE guidance

This patch adds guidance to the HTTP methods about how to interpret the
DELETE method. As discussed at the September 2018 PTG, we want to
encourage an idempotent interpretation of DELETE to reduce the amount of
error handling that clients need to implement.

Change-Id: I1ce452e4553a67f7249196dc0c2d4e3c83ef0d3f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/api-sig refs/changes/10/616610/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * The **DELETE** method should be idempotent. What that means is that you should be able to call DELETE many times against the same resource and not receive an error. The way to understand this is that issuing a DELETE against a resource means "I no longer wish that this resource exists". Do not return an error if the resource doesn't exist. In the rare use cases where it is necessary to verify that a resource was deleted, you should first call a GET or HEAD on that resource, and return an error if it doesn't exist.

commit_message:
CI: Fix symlinks to failed logs

Stop renaming files. Swift should be able to serve text/plain files
based on content, not extension.

Failed logs symlinks were broken because we stopped gzipping log
files and improperly rewrote the logic there.

Change-Id: Idddf51730821644948f51577807f5beaa18c6262
(cherry picked from commit 4a0182f15acbabc88df0aa660abce81d61f528da)
(cherry picked from commit 067770667cf62195580a8406dda1219d6a709f57)

commit_message:
Ensure we don't pass empty addresses to lsp_set_addresses

If we somehow have an empty set of addresses, lsp_set_addresses
will fail. This instead calls db_clear() on the addresses field if
we are trying to set it to empty.

Closes-bug: #1860560

Change-Id: Ied92eb85b74e63a7317d50970b5131fb49e3e4b0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/03/703703/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if addresses: self._nb_idl.lsp_set_addresses( port.name, addresses=addresses).execute(check_error=True) else: self._nb_idl.db_clear( 'Logical_Switch_Port', port.name, 'addresses').execute(check_error=True)

commit_message:
Add package information to the dashboard-plugin relation

Add 'conflicting-packages' and 'install-packages' keys to the
relation so that a plugin can notify the openstack-dashboard charm that
it needs packages installed and what original packages will conflict
with them.

Change-Id: I962ec558b8dd1f765c6104d5ae61edd41c03affe
Related-Bug: #1853851

commit_message:
Use mariabackup for database backups

Kolla ansible switched its database backup support to mariabackup from
xtrabackup due to incompatibilities. See
https://bugs.launchpad.net/kolla/+bug/1843043 for details.

Change-Id: Ib95771f09fd6d5e71a2af471de47f811e1cab88b
Related-Bug: #1843043
Story: 2006952
Task: 37634

commit_message:
Use internal API endpoints in overcloud API interaction

Connections default to 'public' interface when attempting to run
openstack commands.  This breaks setups where the network hosts are
separate from the controllers.

This change adds an ``openstack_interface`` variable to select the
correct endpoint to use, which defaults to ``internal``.

Co-Authored-By: Michael Senizaiz <michael@r-hpc.com>

Change-Id: Ifa766d2cc3ed7077f03c571398072ad5117701c6
Story: 2006814
Task: 37374

commit_message:
Fix use of IPA images in Bifrost without a checksum

Ironic now provides DIB-built CentOS images at
https://tarballs.openstack.org/ironic-python-agent/dib/files. However,
if Bifrost is configured to use these, then the 'kayobe seed service
deploy' command fails because the checksum files are not available.

This change fixes the issue by allowing
'kolla_bifrost_ipa_kernel_checksum_url' and
'kolla_bifrost_ipa_ramdisk_checksum_url' to be overridden to empty
strings, indicating that there is no checksum.

Very similar to the issue fixed in https://review.opendev.org/688359 for
the overcloud.

Change-Id: If73cebb95c7d0596dc8087112fc19398a113f0cc
Story: 2006715
Task: 37407

commit_message:
Fix kayobe overcloud provision without seed in limit

If you run 'kayobe overcloud provision' for the first time on a system,
and do not include the seed in the limit (e.g. --limit overcloud), then
the following error is seen:

    Destination directory /etc/kolla/bifrost/inventory/host_vars does
    not exist

This is because the first play in ansible/kolla-bifrost-hostvars.yml
executes against the seed. This is not ideal, as the --limit argment is
useful with this command, as a way to provision specific nodes.

This change fixes the issue by moving the initialisation tasks to the
second play which is targeted at the overcloud group. The run_once
parameter ensures it happens once.

Change-Id: I7dff72a50f0592a3564c9d84d684db562c30626a
Story: 2006757
Task: 37247

commit_message:
Stop running kolla-target-venv in seed hypervisor host upgrade

We don't run kolla-target-venv during `seed hypervisor host configure`.
This playbook is limited to seed:overcloud anyway.

Change-Id: Ia2c7c151aca75aadc1efc406383b3966d77d4b9e

commit_message:
Don't list tasks for config dump

kayobe executed with --list-tasks often fails due to passing this
argument through to the config dump, which causes it to not generate the
required dump file.

Ignore list-tasks for configuration dump.

Change-Id: I5dccd7d8eab8d46ef5e8cd97a601510a3d8db177
Story: 2006530
Task: 36584

commit_message:
External Ceph: copy also cinder keyring to nova services

Since [1] nova-compute uses rbd python library instead of libvirt to cleanup
volumes and get pool info - so it requires cinder keyring on filesystem.

In external ceph case it is often that nova key does not exist (is simply a copied
cinder key) and the rbd user is set to cinder - therefore the earlier mentioned
operations will fail due to a missing keyring on the filesystem.

[1]: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/668564/

Change-Id: Idef21dc5f7e9ff512bc8920630a3de61a1e69eee
Backport: train
Closes-Bug: #1859408

subject: Allow ironic_ipxe to serve instance images
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-12-12 14:41:18.000000000', 'files': ['releasenotes/notes/ironic-ipxe-instance-image-47fb3c9f0edef5f5.yaml', 'ansible/roles/ironic/defaults/main.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible/commit/2b662cfb127c9abc4930c498d7f9957a8065f5ce', 'message': 'Allow ironic_ipxe to serve instance images

Ironic provides a feature to allow instance images to be served from a
local HTTP server [1]. This is the same server used for PXE images with
iPXE. This does not work currently because the ironic_ipxe container
does not have access to /var/lib/ironic/images (ironic docker volume),
where the images are cached. Note that to make use of this feature, the
following is required in ironic.conf:

[agent]
image_download_source = http

This change fixes the issue by giving ironic_ipxe container access to
the ironic volume.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/ironic/latest/admin/interfaces/deploy.html#deploy-with-custom-http-servers

Change-Id: I501d02cfd40fbacea32d551c3912640c5661d821
Closes-Bug: #1856194
'}]
commit_message:
Allow ironic_ipxe to serve instance images

Ironic provides a feature to allow instance images to be served from a
local HTTP server [1]. This is the same server used for PXE images with
iPXE. This does not work currently because the ironic_ipxe container
does not have access to /var/lib/ironic/images (ironic docker volume),
where the images are cached. Note that to make use of this feature, the
following is required in ironic.conf:

[agent]
image_download_source = http

This change fixes the issue by giving ironic_ipxe container access to
the ironic volume.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/ironic/latest/admin/interfaces/deploy.html#deploy-with-custom-http-servers

Change-Id: I501d02cfd40fbacea32d551c3912640c5661d821
Closes-Bug: #1856194

commit_message:
Add also_notifies to Infoblox backend for Designate

Change-Id: Ia02f83dfaaba53f95e373b2b2be3f74cfb7ae578
Closes-Bug: #1855085
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/67/697267/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - | Adds configuration to set `also_notifies` within the pools.yaml file when using the Infoblox backend for Designate. Pushing a DNS NOTIFY packet to the master does not cause the DNS update to be propagated onto other nodes within the cluster. This means each node needs a DNS NOTIFY packet otherwise users may be given a stale DNS record if they query any worker node. For details please see <https://bugs.launchpad.net/kolla-ansible/+bug/1855085>`__.

commit_message:
Fix Prometheus template generation

In a deployment where Prometheus is enabled and
Alertmanager is disabled the task "Copying over
prometheus config file" in
'ansible/roles/prometheus/tasks/config.yml' will
fail to template the Prometheus configuration file
'ansible/roles/prometheus/templates/prometheus.yml.j2'
as the variable 'prometheus_alert_rules' does not
contain the key 'files'. This commit fixes this bug.

Change-Id: Idbe1e52dd3693a6f168d475f9230a253dae64480
Closes-Bug: #1854540

subject: [OVN] Use STACK_USER's actual primary group in starting services
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-01-20 12:52:51.000000000', 'files': ['devstack/lib/ovn_agent'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/426afcfe024249a7e3df551e5512b2da10410282', 'message': "[OVN] Use STACK_USER's actual primary group in starting services

devstack/lib/ovn_agent previously hardcoded the expectation that there
is a group with the same name as $STACK_USER. This group exists in a
default Ubuntu installation, but not in all possible systems.

Change-Id: I2015157e07f8284199cd4926d7d83bc1bb637339
"}]
commit_message:
[OVN] Use STACK_USER's actual primary group in starting services

devstack/lib/ovn_agent previously hardcoded the expectation that there
is a group with the same name as $STACK_USER. This group exists in a
default Ubuntu installation, but not in all possible systems.

This change starts all services previously using this group under
$STACK_USER's actual primary group.

Change-Id: I2015157e07f8284199cd4926d7d83bc1bb637339

commit_message:
Positive tests for security group quota

1. Test supported values for securiyt group quota
2. Test creating maximum allowed amount of security groups
3. Test creating maximum allowed amount of security groups if
quota is increased
4. Test decreasing security group quota to a value that is less
than amount of already created security groups
5. Test creating security groups when the quota is disabled (set to -1)

Change-Id: I833e5d5e67ef7555c9e6a54613b7324310079b0b

commit_message:
Install virsh for Centos

Virsh binary is not part of the package libvirt-daemon-kvm and it's not
installed by dependecy. So `libvirt_package` was converted to a list
and `libvirt-client` is installed additionally, which provides virsh.

Change-Id: I967fd6e20e18310b4599fa00d003d7424ed73ae5
(cherry picked from commit 3e03cd19193e882c219598cfc4636e92cddb5d4d)

commit_message:
Follow up to change of exception raised

The patch in the Depends-On line changed the class of an exception
raised in neutron-lib. This change adapts neutron code where we expected
the exception changed.

Change-Id: I34f7d2aab0af0b985d9165465fe9e7c656041745
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/695205

commit_message:
Copy volume to image in multiple stores of glance

Change-Id: Ic7f259c3af6bd691e6d24ed180430e760d28eba8
Implements: copy-image-in-multiple-stores
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/30/695630/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================== Image snapshot co-location ========================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/image-snapshot-co-location This specs propose to send base image reference to glance on volume upload to image API. Problem description =================== In Train, Glance has added the ability to configure multiple stores [1]_. This way an operator can configure more than one of similar or different kind of stores and use one as a default store. If a store is not specified at the time of uploading an image then the image will be stored in default store. In case of cinder copying volume to image, if no changes are made to cinder, even if multiple stores are configured then the image will be uploaded to default store. This does not cause any issues, but does not allow an operator to take advantage of Glance multiple stores. Use Cases ========= 1. An operator is offering multiple Glance image stores distinguished by some desirability metric (as explained to end users in each store's description) and wants a user to have the option to select which of these stores will be used to store an image created from a Cinder volume. 2. The base image from which volume is created is resides in multiple stores and operator wants the image created from Cinder volume should also be uploaded to all stores where the base image is stored. Proposed change =============== In case if volume is created using image then it stores the image uuid in 'volume_image_metadata'. When Cinder upload volume to image is requested cinder should pass the 'image uuid' as a header 'x-openstack-base-image-ref' to glance, so that glance will identify in which store the base image is stored and use that same store to upload the image created from volume. Cinder is also storing this glance store information in volume types [2]_, where the store identifier associated with volume type will be passed as a header 'x-image-meta-store' to glance to upload the image created from volume to that specific store. If volume is created from image and Cinder passes both 'x-openstack-base-image-ref' and store information is also available in volume types then glance will ignore the header 'x-openstack-base-image-ref' and will continue store associated with volume type. If volume is created from image and Cinder does not provode 'x-openstack-base-image-ref' and store information in volume types then glance will use 'default store' to upload the image created from volume. If volume is not bootable and store information is available in volume types then glance will use store associated with volume type to upload the image created from volume. If volume is not bootable and store information is not available in volume types then glance will use 'default store' to upload the image created from volume. Alternatives ------------ Continue with passing store information using volume types [2]_. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Active/Active HA impact ----------------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: whoami-rajat Other contributors: abhishek-kekane Work Items ---------- * Pass image uuid stored in 'volume_image_metadata' as header to glance * Add related tests Dependencies ============ * Depends on implementation of 'Support Glance multiple stores' [2]_. Testing ======= * Add related unittest * Add related functional test * Add tempest tests Documentation Impact ==================== Operators documentation should be updated according to spec implementation. References ========== .. [1] https://docs.openstack.org/glance/rocky/admin/multistores.html .. [2] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/cinder-specs/specs/train/support-glance-multiple-backend.html

commit_message:
Add api_prefix for check capabilities

The swift api is organized as
host:port/info and host:port/v1/AUTH_<tenant-id> [1]
With the latter being registered as Swift endpoint
in the Keystone catalog. Tempest tests for swift capabilities
seem to cut all path from the API endpoint and append 'info' to it,
however Ceph's RadosGW has a 'swift' prefix in its API [2]
(as it supports S3 api too) like
host:port/swift/info and host:port/swift/v1/AUTH_<tenant-id>
so those tests fail on RadosGW as they attempt to access the
wrong capabilities url w/o swift prefix.

The patch also makes 3 tests skipped because they are relying on some
constraints which are not available in a non swift deployment
(see the bug for more info).

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/object-store/
[2] https://docs.ceph.com/docs/master/radosgw/config-ref/#swift-settings

Close-bug: 1799981
Change-Id: I22c5ea2567915b872ef3ff6378542d3233407a88

commit_message:
[Stein Only] Add step to upgrade ceph after upgrading the OS.

After upgrading the Controller's Operating System we need to
run an additional step if Ceph is enabled in the system. This
step will change the systemd unit to operate with podman
instead of docker.

Then, once Controller's upgrade finished we'll run the ceph
external-upgrade steps.

Change-Id: Ie33707f29ab0553a558e101bc6fb6f7f77d394f0

commit_message:
[DNM] Fluentd / Kafka Consumer Group Config Example

These scripts establish three topics within kafka along with
a producer and consumer group for each topic.

Change-Id: I06e137ece2541468a568d5555507d7b3d3ed8c0b
